title: Computing Shrines
subtext: a collection of site-specific objects turning shared spaces into spaces for sharing and open protocol for doing so
descriptionMd:
We face a loneliness epidemic as free third spaces for communities disappear, and our devices have become symbols of isolation. Computing Shrines responds to this crisis by reimagining technology as a public good for fostering local connection rather than replacing it.
Each shrine consists of a passively powered structure that connects visitors' phones to a site-specific web experience, built around an interactive exchange between past and future visitors. These websites can only be accessed at their shrine, anchoring a virtual space to a physical place. As digital-physical objects, these shrines become living archives of the collective everyday interactions of the people who steward the space, from the physical patina and graffiti to the virtual traces and stories contributed.
For example, "Shrine to Voice" is mobile phone booth that invites visitors to listen to the last person’s voice and share their worries and hopes with the next stranger. “Shrine to Earth" is a boulder that invites visitors to share photos of rocks they’ve found, which become pieces in a rock-stacking mini-game. And in "Shrine to Others," a clay tablet invites connection with others by prompting visitors to note the qualities they appreciate in strangers.
Beyond an installation, Computing Shrines is an open protocol for creating public good technology. Designed with common materials and electronics, open-sourcing the web experiences, and collaboratively collecting instructions by local stewards, the project transforms the normally solitary and exclusive act of creating technology into a community improvement project for all to shape.
Supported by [APOSSIBLE](https://apossible.com/), [DAL](https://dalab.xyz/en/), and [NEW INC](https://newinc.org/). 
- June 4-22: [Embodied Algorithms / Collective Mechanics](https://www.demofestival.org/showcases/art-and-code) by NEW INC and the New Museum, Curated by Sheldon Gooch
materials: location-bound websites, RFID chips, mixed materials including acrylic, ceramics, found stone, and silicone.
